chapter.title: Configuring the &THIS.PLATFORM; Media Server
chapter.para: The &THIS.PLATFORM; Media Server is developed on top of existing Java technologies. The Java platform is ideal for network computing. It offers single, unified-and-unifying programming model that can connect all elements of a business infrastructure. The modularization effort is supported by use of the JBoss Microcontainer which allows to deploy services written as Plain Java Objects into a Standard Java SE runtime environment in controlled manner and achieve great level of customization.

section.title: MainDeployer
section.para: The configurable aspects of MainDeployer are:

listitem.para: Specifies the location of the configuration XML files. By default, this is the /deploy directory.
Specifies the file extensions that will be deployed or monitored. Supported file extensions are -beans.xml and -conf.xml

section.title: Server instance
section.para: The modularization effort allows the user to construct and start more then one instance of the media server in the single JBoss microcontainer. The single server instance is defined by the following description:

example.title: The Media Server instance Declaration
example.programlisting: <bean name="MediaServer" class="org.mobicents.media.Server"> <property name="rtpManager"><inject bean="RTPFactory"/></property> <incallback method="addFactory" /> <uncallback method="removeFactory" /> </bean>

section.para: The configurable aspects of the server instance are:

listitem.para: Specifies the relationship between the Real Time Transmission Protocol Manager and the server instance.

section.para: It is possible to run several Media Server instances with different RTP configurations. These configurations are used when the Media Server acts as a gateway at the boundaries of the different networks.

section.para: Each media type to be processed must be declared. Below is an example declaration of Audio and Video media types.

section.title: Media Format
section.para: Format specifies a particular arrangement of data in a media stream. By examining the information stored in the format, components can discover how to interpret the bits in the binary sound data. Format accommodates a number of common encoding techniques, including pulse-code modulation (PCM), mu-law encoding or a-law encoding. These encoding techniques are predefined, but the user can create new encoding types.
In addition to the encoding, the format includes other properties that further specify the exact arrangement of the data which are specific for each media type.

section.title: Audio Format
section.para: Audio specific parameters include the number of channels, sample rate, sample size and byte order. Sounds may have different numbers of audio channels (for example, one stereo and two mono). The sample rate measures how many "snapshots" (samples) of the sound pressure are taken per second, per channel.

note.para: If the sound is stereo rather than mono, two samples are actually measured at each instant of time: one for the left channel, and another for the right channel. However, the sample rate still measures the number per channel, so the rate is the same regardless of the number of channels. This is the standard use of the term.

section.para: The sample size indicates how many bits are used to store each snapshot; 8 and 16 are typical values. For 16-bit samples (or any other sample size larger than a byte), byte order is important - the bytes in each sample are arranged in either the "little-endian" or "big-endian" style.
The respective parameters of the audio format are:

listitem.para: Encoding name
Sample rate
Sample size in bits
Number of channels

section.title: RTP Audio Video profile
section.para: Real-time audio and video conferencing and communication applications that use the Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP) employ a standardized description format (Session Description Protocol, SDP) to describe the media streams carried in a multi-media session.

This description format specifies the technical parameters of the media streams. Such a set of RTP parameters of the media stream and its compression or encoding methods is known as a media profile, or RTP audio video profile (RTP/AVP). Each profile is identified by a standardized payload type identifier (RFC 3551 and others).

table.title: RTP/AVP audio and video payload types

section.para: Payload identifiers 96â€“127 are reserved for payloads defined dynamically during a session. The minimum payload support is defined as 0 (PCMU) and 5 (DVI4). Dynamically assigned port numbers are recommended, although 5004 and 5005 have been registered for use by the profile and can be used instead.
Dynamic payloads can be configured using the Format description and the A/V Profile description.

section.title: RTP Manager
section.para: This is the starting point for creating, maintaining and closing an RTP session. RTP Manager supports unicast sessions only.
The configurable aspects of the RTPFactory are:

listitem.para: List of encoders/decoders that this RtpFactory is capable of transcoding.
Specifies the IP address which will be used for the RTP session.
Indicates whether UA supports silence suppression. Set to true if silence suppression is supported.
Lowest port (in the range of lowest to highest ports) available for creating RTP sessions. The first free port in the given range is assigned to the session.
Highest port (in the range of lowest to highest ports) available for creating RTP sessions. The first free port in the given range is assigned to the session.
Specifies the size of the jitter buffer (in milliseconds) for incoming packets.

example.title: RTP Manager definition
example.programlisting: <bean name="RTPFactory" class="org.mobicents.media.server.impl.rtp.RtpFactory"> <property name="bindAddress">${mms.bind.address}</property> <property name="silenceSuppression">true</property> <property name="jitter">100</property> <property name="lowPort">1024</property> <property name="highPort">65535</property> <property name="codecs"> <map class="java.util.Hashtable" keyClass="org.mobicents.media.server.spi.MediaType" valueClass="java.util.List"> <entry> <key><inject bean="MediaType.audio"></inject></key> <value> <list> <inject bean="G711.ulaw.encoder" /> <inject bean="G711.ulaw.decoder" /> </list> </value> </entry> </map> </property> </bean>

section.title: Dual-tone multi-frequency (DTMF) tones
section.para: Dual-tone multi-frequency (DTMF) signaling is used for telephone signaling over the line in the voice-frequency band to the call switching center. The version of DTMF used for telephone tone dialing is known by the trademarked term Touch-Tone, and is standardised by ITU-T Recommendation Q.23. Other multi-frequency systems are used for signaling internal to the telephone network

section.title: Voice pool configuration
section.para: The Media Server has a pool of voices. At startup, it creates the desired number of voice generating objects. This reduces runtime overhead and delays in response from the server. The size of the pool, for each voice, can be configured via the media player configuration property: voices.
The Voices property is of the type Map. The table below describes the values stored in this property:

row.entry: Defines pool name. It must match correct voice name, ie: alan
Defines size of pool for voice. It must be positive integer.

section.programlisting:
<bean name="media.audio" class="org.mobicents.media.server.impl.resource.mediaplayer.audio.AudioPlayerFactory"> <property name="name">media.player</property> <property name="audioMediaDirectory">${mms.media.dir}</property>
<property name="voices"> <map class="java.util.Hashtable" keyClass="java.lang.String" valueClass="java.lang.Integer">
<entry> <key>alan</key> <value>1</value> </entry> <entry> <key>kevin16</key> <value>1</value> </entry> <entry> <key>kevin</key> <value>1</value> </entry> <entry> <key>mbrola_us3</key> <value>1</value> </entry> <entry> <key>mbrola_us2</key> <value>1</value> </entry> <entry> <key>mbrola_us1</key> <value>1</value> </entry>
</map> </property>
</bean>

section.title: Connection state manager
section.para: The Connection can be in one of the following four operational states.

listitem.para: The Connection has been installed successfully and is ready to be activated. The Connection is not running (it is not receiving or transmitting media).

The receiving and/or transmitting Channels of the Connection are connected to a Sink and/or a Source of an Endpoint. However, the Connection is still not running. (it is not receiving or transmitting media). The Connection transits back to NULL when deleted in this stage.
The Connection is bound and can only receive media. The Connection transits back to NULL when deleted in this stage.
The remote SDP is set and now the Connection can receive as well as transmit media. The Connection transits back to NULL when deleted in this stage.

section.para: There is no direct control over the states of Connection, only through the Controller module.
The ConnectionStateManager maps the various states of Connection, with the lifetime (in milliseconds) of each Connection included.

important.para: The Connection will be deleted after timeout value specified for that state has been reached, whether it is running or not.

section.title: MGCP controller configuration
section.para: The MGCP Controller is implemented by the following component:
section.programlisting: <bean name="MgcpController" class="org.mobicents.media.server.ctrl.mgcp.MgcpController"> <property name="server"> <inject bean="MediaServer" /> </property> <property name="defaultNotifiedEntity">client@localhost:2727</property> <property name="bindAddress">${mms.bind.address}</property> <property name="port">2427</property> <incallback method="addPackage" /> <uncallback method="removePackage" /> </bean>
section.para: The configurable aspects of the MGCP controller are:

listitem.para: The server instance which is under control.
The IP address to which the controller is bound.
The port number used by the controller.
Defines the default notified entity value.
